hedline.hl1: 2 Chains Halting Sales of Drugs in Capsules

block.p: Two large drugstore chains have halted all sales of over-the-counter drugs in capsules after poisoned Sudafed capsules were found in their stores.

The move affects 17 different brands of products, including some of the most popular decongestants and diet aids, like Contac and Dexatrim, said a spokesman for one of the chains, Pay'n Save Drug Stores. The chain operates 124 stores in Alaska, Hawaii, Idaho and Washington. The other company banning capsule sales is Western Drug Distributors Inc., which operates 11 stores in Washington State. Spokesmen for the companies said they did not know how long the bans would last.
Two large drugstore chains have halted all sales of over-the-counter drugs in capsules after poisoned Sudafed capsules were found in their stores.

The move affects 17 different brands of products, including some of the most popular decongestants and diet aids, like Contac and Dexatrim, said a spokesman for one of the chains, Pay'n Save Drug Stores. The chain operates 124 stores in Alaska, Hawaii, Idaho and Washington. The other company banning capsule sales is Western Drug Distributors Inc., which operates 11 stores in Washington State. Spokesmen for the companies said they did not know how long the bans would last.

Sudafed decongestant capsules tainted with cyanide killed two people and injured a third in the State of Washington, officials said. Federal officials investigating the episode said they might ban all over-the-counter drugs in capsules or urge manufacturers to drop them voluntarily.

One tainted Sudafed capsule was found at a Pay'n Save store and two were found at Drug Emporiums, which are operated by Western Drug. One of the Sudafed capsules bought at a Drug Emporium resulted in the injury.

Two major national drugstore chains, the Jack Eckerd Corporation, of Clearwater, Fla., and the Walgreen Company, of Deerfield, Ill., said yesterday that they had no plans to suspend sales of capsules.
The Burroughs Wellcome Company of Research Triangle Park, N.C., which makes Sudafed 12-Hour capsules, has recalled the product nationwide.
